items.synopsis: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has continued to defy public pressure to immediately step down, by announcing he will retire next year, while the Australian share market is set to rise in morning trade as concerns about higher-for-longer interest rates subsided. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas board set for a shakeup as Richard Goyder becomes the latest high-profile exit, ASX to follow Wall Street higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Outgoing Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has released a short statement after announcing his retirement from the role ahead of the airline's 2024 AGM. He said the board has recognised the "significant reputation and customer service issues" plaguing the airline, and is c ommitted to taking accountability. Here's his full statement: "As a board, we acknowledge the significant reputation and customer service issues facing the group and recognise that accountability is required to restore trust. "Qantas has gone through an incredibly difficult period since our operation was grounded during the pandemic. "The recovery has not been easy, and mistakes were made. We again apologise for those times where we got it wrong. "I have always sought to act in the best interests of Qantas. Measured and orderly succession at board level will support the important work underway led by Vanessa [Hudson] and her new management team. "Fundamentally, the group is in a very strong position to overcome its current challenges and deliver for all its stakeholders in the years ahead."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Outgoing Qantas chair Goyder says 'accountability is required to restore trust'

children.content: Outgoing Qantas chairman Richard Goyder
has released a short statement after announcing his retirement from the role ahead of the airline's 2024 AGM.
He said the board has recognised the "significant reputation and customer service issues" plaguing the airline, and is c
ommitted to taking accountability
Here's his full statement:
"As a board, we
acknowledge the significant reputation and customer service issues
facing the group and recognise that
accountability is required to restore trust
"Qantas has gone through an incredibly difficult period since our operation was grounded during the pandemic.
"The recovery has not been easy, and
mistakes were made
. We again apologise for those times where we got it wrong.
"I have always sought to act in the best interests of Qantas. Measured and
orderly succession at board level will support the important work underway led by Vanessa [Hudson]
and her new management team.
"Fundamentally, the group is in a very strong position to overcome its current challenges and deliver for all its stakeholders in the years ahead."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has revealed that its chairman Richard Goyder will retire before the company’s annual general meeting in late 2024. The airline says a number of other board members will retire throughout the next year “in recognition of the reputational issues facing the Group and to support restoration of trust in the company”. Non-executive director Michael L'estrange will retire at this year's AGM on November 3. Jacqueline Hey and Maxine Brenner will retire when Qantas' half-year results are published in February next year. Mr Goyder has been under increasing public pressure to leave Qantas, following the departure of former chief executive Alan Joyce. The company's reputation was hurt in recent years by its poor customer service, frequently losing baggage, late-running and cancelled flights, and sharply increased airfare — while posting a record profit. Its public standing was damaged further when the competition regulator (the ACCC ) sued the airline in court for allegedly selling thousands of tickets for flights that it knew had already cancelled. In addition, the High Court rules that the airline had illegally sacked 1,700 ground handling staff, under the leadership of Mr Goyder and Mr Joyce (as chairman and CEO). In late September, Mr Goyder was grilled in a Senate inquiry, but dismissed calls for him to step down. His decision to leave by next year's annual general meeting in November 2024 (instead of next month's AGM) shows he's continuing to defy public pressure. Its share price has plummeted by more than 21% in the past three months.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Richard Goyder to retire as Qantas chairman ... next year

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I'll be guiding you through the latest finance news on this fine hump day. The local share share market is likley to begin its day higher, with ASX futures up 0.4%. The Australian dollar rose 0.3% to 64.3 US cents. It follows a solid day on Wall Street, with the S & P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rising 0.5% and 0.6% respectively, to their highest level in three weeks. The Dow Jones index gained 0.4%. Oil prices retreated, with Brent crude futures down 0.8% to $US87.42 per barrel. Spot gold was steady at $US1,860 an ounce. But while oil prices eased after Monday's rally, investors were still closely monitoring developments in the Middle East. US Fed driving share markets higher Worries about borrowing costs staying higher for longer subsided a little overnight. That's after the interest rate on the US government's long-term debt posted their largest daily drop since mid-July. In particular, the US 10-year Treasury yield fell 10.6 basis points (bps) to 4.68% (which is still near a 15-year high overall). The catalyst appears to be some 'dovish' comments from top-ranking Federal Reserve officials, including Fed Vice Chair Philip Jefferson. On Monday, he indicated that the recent jump in US Treasury yields (which directly influence financing costs for households and businesses) might mean the Fed doesn't need to lift its benchmark interest rate. Then on Tuesday (local time), Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Raphael Bostic said the central bank does not need to raise interest rates any further, and sees no recession ahead (even as the Fed's rate hikes so far slow the economy and bring down inflation).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Dovish' Fed comments drive Wall Street higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tim Callanan Representatives of the Australian Jewish and Palestinian communities have condemned anti-Semitic chants reported to have been shouted at pro-Palestinian demonstrations this week. Rallies were held in Sydney and Melbourne over the last two nights in support of Palestinians. The president of the Zionist Federation of Australi a, Jeremy Leibler, said some of the slogans being chanted at the Sydney demonstration were unacceptable. “I’m terrified when I see these marches through the city that are not holding candles and calling for peace as we see from rallies in the Jewish community when things have flared up in the Middle East,” he told ABC Radio Melbourne. “What we’re seeing is violent protests.” Mr Leibler said the response from Australian political leaders so far has been heartening. “I think we’ve had strong, very principled support – bipartisan support – both from the prime minister, from [opposition leader] Peter Dutton, and both at the state leadership levels as well,” he said. “So there should be. As there was after 9/11.” President of the Palestine Advocacy Network, Nasser Mashni, said he was disappointed by some of the language used at the pro-Palestinian demonstrations. “It’s entirely unacceptable. There is no room in our movement for antisemitism, any level of racism, Islamophobia, whatever,” he said. “Our struggle is an anti-colonial struggle for self-determination for all peoples in the holy land.” However, he said the move to project the Israeli flag on the Sydney Opera House was hurtful for Australians with a Palestinian background. “I’m Australian too, why don’t my children matter? When the [Sydney] Opera House is lit up in the Israeli flag there was an opportunity for Australia to have a moment of bringing together all peoples to say all children matter,” he said. “Both the flags could have been there.” Meanwhile, Victoria Police is investigating reports of antisemitic threats made in South Yarra yesterday. Police said the occupants of a car threatened a man on Toorak Road about 4pm yesterday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Entirely unacceptable': Australian Jewish, Palestinian communities condemn anti-Semitic chants

children.content: Reporting by
Tim Callanan
Representatives of the Australian Jewish and Palestinian communities have condemned anti-Semitic chants reported to have been shouted at pro-Palestinian demonstrations this week.
Rallies were held in Sydney and Melbourne over the last two nights in support of Palestinians.
The president of the
Zionist Federation of Australi
a, Jeremy Leibler, said some of the slogans being chanted at the Sydney demonstration were unacceptable.

“I’m terrified when I see these marches through the city that are not holding candles and calling for peace as we see from rallies in the Jewish community when things have flared up in the Middle East,” he told ABC Radio Melbourne.
“What we’re seeing is violent protests.”
Mr Leibler said the response from Australian political leaders so far has been heartening.

“I think we’ve had strong, very principled support – bipartisan support – both from the prime minister, from [opposition leader] Peter Dutton, and both at the state leadership levels as well,” he said.
“So there should be. As there was after 9/11.”
The demonstration at Sydney Opera House on Monday night.
(AAP: Dean Lewis)
President of the
Palestine Advocacy Network
, Nasser Mashni, said he was disappointed by some of the language used at the pro-Palestinian demonstrations.
“It’s entirely unacceptable. There is no room in our movement for antisemitism, any level of racism, Islamophobia, whatever,” he said.
“Our struggle is an anti-colonial struggle for self-determination for all peoples in the holy land.”
However, he said the move to project the Israeli flag on the Sydney Opera House was hurtful for Australians with a Palestinian background.

“I’m Australian too, why don’t my children matter? When the [Sydney] Opera House is lit up in the Israeli flag there was an opportunity for Australia to have a moment of bringing together all peoples to say all children matter,” he said.
“Both the flags could have been there.”
Meanwhile,
Victoria Police
is investigating reports of antisemitic threats made in South Yarra yesterday.
Police said the occupants of a car threatened a man on Toorak Road about 4pm yesterday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Jake Evans The Australian Jewry Council has confirmed an Australian grandmother was killed in the attack launched by Hamas. In a statement, the council's co-CEO Alex Ryvchin said the community was devastated to learn of the woman's death. "The Australian Jewish community is already devastated and confirmation of an Australian grandmother murdered in her home brings us new pain and sorrow," Mr Ryvchin said. "We mourn with the Carbone family at this terrible time and stand with the people of Israel and all the nations affected by this mass atrocity." Several media outlets have reported the woman killed was 66-year-old Galit Carbone, who was born in Sydney and moved to Israel as a teenager.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian grandmother killed in Israel

featuredLink.title: Australian grandmother confirmed killed in Israel

children.content: Reporting by Jake Evans
The
Australian Jewry Council
has confirmed an Australian grandmother was killed in the attack launched by Hamas.
In a statement, the council's co-CEO Alex Ryvchin said the community was devastated to learn of the woman's death.
"The Australian Jewish community is already devastated and confirmation of an Australian grandmother murdered in her home brings us new pain and sorrow," Mr Ryvchin said.
"We mourn with the Carbone family at this terrible time and stand with the people of Israel and all the nations affected by this mass atrocity."
Several media outlets have reported the woman killed was 66-year-old
Galit Carbone
, who was born in Sydney and moved to Israel as a teenager.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fears are growing that the conflict could expand beyond Gaza, with Israel also facing wider threats and shared hostility from other non-state actors. Nicholas Blanford, a non-resident senior fellow with the Atlantic Council's Middle East Programs, told ABC News Radio Hezbollah was a very real and formidable threat to Israel. "It's a very close ally of the Hamas movement, so what is going in Gaza now has a direct impact on Hezbollah," he said. While the two groups are different the two share many similarities especially when it comes to shared hostility towards Israel. "In fact, the unprecedented operation Hamas conducted on Saturday breaking out of the Gaza, and entering the Israeli settlements around Gaza was straight out of Hezbollah's playbook," he said speaking from Beirut. "A massive rocket barrage, infiltration on mass across the border to cause as much damage and chaos as possible inside Israel. "Hezbollah have been training since 2007 but in this case it was Hamas which put it into practice with deadly effect." But he noted Hezbollah faced constraints with shots still being called by Iran, so if the group was told to go to all-out war with Israel they would. But he also said he wasn’t certain Hezbollah would want to face an all-out conflict knowing it would erode its “potent capabilities” further down the road. You can listen to News Radio live and more coverage of the conflict at the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas attack was 'right out of Hezbollah's playbook'

children.content: Fears are growing that the conflict could expand beyond Gaza, with Israel also facing wider threats and shared hostility from other non-state actors.
Nicholas Blanford,
a non-resident senior fellow with the Atlantic Council's Middle East Programs, told ABC News Radio
Hezbollah
was a very real and formidable threat to Israel.
"It's a very close ally of the Hamas movement,
so what is going in Gaza now has a direct impact on Hezbollah," he said.
While the two groups are different the two share many similarities especially when it comes to shared hostility towards Israel.

"In fact, the unprecedented operation Hamas conducted on Saturday breaking out of the Gaza, and entering the Israeli settlements around Gaza was straight out of Hezbollah's playbook," he said speaking from Beirut.
"A massive rocket barrage, infiltration on mass across the border to cause as much damage and chaos as possible inside Israel.
"Hezbollah have been training since 2007 but in this case it was Hamas which put it into practice with deadly effect."
But he noted Hezbollah faced constraints with shots still being called by Iran, so if the group was told to go to all-out war with Israel they would.
But he also said he wasn’t certain Hezbollah would want to face an all-out conflict knowing it would erode its “potent capabilities” further down the road.
You can listen to News Radio live and more coverage of the conflict at the link below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In a couple of hours we'll hear Western Australian senator Patrick Dodson 's National Press Club address. Mr Dodson is also the special envoy for reconciliation and implementation of the Uluru Statement from the Heart. Previously, Mr Dodson was director of the Central and Kimberley Land Councils and a Commissioner in the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. His address will begin at 12:30pm AEDT. We'll be bringing you a live stream as well as blogging Mr Dodson's address.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Patrick Dodson to address National Press Club

(ABC News)

Western Australian senator Patrick Dodson
's National Press Club address.
Mr Dodson is also the special envoy for reconciliation and implementation of the Uluru Statement from the Heart.
Previously, Mr Dodson was director of the Central and Kimberley Land Councils and a Commissioner in the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.
His address will begin at

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney says she is "shocked" by comments made by the Opposition leader about late Northern Territory land rights advocate, Yunupiŋu. Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year Yunupiŋu died earlier this year aged 74, after a lifetime spent trying to better the outcomes of his Yolŋu people in north-east Arnhem Land. Earlier today, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton equated Yunupiŋu's work towards improving his Arnhem Land community with why a Voice to Parliament wasn't needed. "They've got a logging company, they've got a building company, they've got housing, they've got a functioning society … because of the leadership demonstrated by Yunupiŋu and others around him over the course of a long period, and that's what we want to see replicated elsewhere," he said. Mr Dutton's comments in Adelaide did not account for the fact that the East Arnhem local government area (LGA) remains one of the 10 most disadvantaged LGAs in Australia. In reaction, Ms Burney says she was "shocked at that statement". "Yunupiŋu spent his entire life fighting for his people, fighting for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people across this country and also advocating a Voice to Parliament," she said. "Quite frankly, Peter Dutton should apologise for taking the name of Yunupiŋu in vain. "The idea that there isn't disadvantage in north-east Arnhem Land is patently ridiculous. "Peter Dutton has no right at all to use the name of Yunupiŋu in that way." NOTE: Yunupiŋu's surname and image is used as per the wishes of his family.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Call for Peter Dutton to apologise over Yunupiŋu comments

children.content: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton (left) and Indigenous Australias Minister Linda Burney (right)
(ABC News)
Reporting by Matt Garrick
Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney
says she is "shocked" by comments made by the Opposition leader about late Northern Territory land rights advocate,
Yunupiŋu
Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year Yunupiŋu
died earlier this year aged 74
, after a lifetime spent trying to better the outcomes of his Yolŋu people in north-east Arnhem Land.
Earlier today,
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton
equated Yunupiŋu's work towards improving his Arnhem Land community with why a Voice to Parliament wasn't needed.

"They've got a logging company, they've got a building company, they've got housing, they've got a functioning society … because of the leadership demonstrated by Yunupiŋu and others around him over the course of a long period, and that's what we want to see replicated elsewhere," he said.
Mr Dutton's comments in Adelaide did not account for the fact that the East Arnhem local government area (LGA) remains one of the
10 most disadvantaged LGAs in Australia
In reaction, Ms Burney says she was "shocked at that statement".
"Yunupiŋu spent his entire life fighting for his people, fighting for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people across this country and also advocating a Voice to Parliament," she said.
"Quite frankly, Peter Dutton should apologise for taking the name of Yunupiŋu in vain.
"The idea that there isn't disadvantage in north-east Arnhem Land is patently ridiculous.
"Peter Dutton has no right at all to use the name of Yunupiŋu in that way."
NOTE: Yunupiŋu's surname and image is used as per the wishes of his family.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Twenty five Australian of the Year recipients have penned an open letter to the public, urging them to vote Yes on Saturday. They say the Yes vote could start to repair the "devastating impact" of colonisation on the welfare of Indigenous Australians. "The effective exclusion of Indigenous voices from decision-making has been at best useless and costly and, at worst, damaging, blocking any meaningful progress," they said. "There is overwhelming evidence that, when given a voice, services are effective and lead to improvements in outcomes, as happened during the Covid pandemic." "The Voice is about ensuring that our First Nations people have a genuine say in matters that impact on their lives. "A Yes vote is a step to a more united and cohesive nation, conscious of the past and looking together to the future." Signatories of the letter include : Dylan Alcott Rosie Batty Taryn Brumfitt Rob de Castella Mick Dodson Peter Doherty John Farnham Tim Flannery Cathy Freeman Adam Gilchrist Adam Goodes Evonne Goolagong Shane Gould Richard Harris Patrick McGorry Simon McKeon David Morrison Gustav Nossal Lowitja O'Donoghue Keith Potger Dick Smith Fiona Stanley Grace Tame Fiona Wood John Yu
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Once in a lifetime opportunity': Australians of the Year write open letter urging Yes vote

children.content: John Farnham (left) and Cathy Freeman (right) have both signed the open letter.
(AAP: Joel Carrett, ABC: Helena Burke)
Twenty five Australian of the Year recipients have penned an open letter to the public,
urging them to vote Yes on Saturday
They say the Yes vote could start to repair the "devastating impact" of colonisation on the welfare of Indigenous Australians.
"The effective exclusion of Indigenous voices from decision-making has been at best useless and costly and, at worst, damaging, blocking any meaningful progress," they said.
"There is overwhelming evidence that, when given a voice, services are effective and lead to improvements in outcomes, as happened during the Covid pandemic."
"The Voice is about ensuring that our First Nations people have a genuine say in matters that impact on their lives.
"A Yes vote is a step to a more united and cohesive nation, conscious of the past and looking together to the future."
Signatories of the letter include
Dylan Alcott
Rosie Batty
Taryn Brumfitt
Rob de Castella
Mick Dodson
Peter Doherty
John Farnham
Tim Flannery
Cathy Freeman
Adam Gilchrist
Adam Goodes
Evonne Goolagong
Shane Gould
Richard Harris
Patrick McGorry
Simon McKeon
David Morrison
Gustav Nossal
Lowitja O'Donoghue
Keith Potger
Dick Smith
Fiona Stanley
Grace Tame
Fiona Wood
John Yu

items.synopsis: As the search for survivors ends, relief efforts are underway and in an area of Afghanistan that was badly hit in an earthquake earlier this year, even beggars are donating what they can to help.

title.children: Afghanistan pleads for help after deadly earthquake reduced villages to rubble and dust

image.altText: Silhouette of a man standing on a shoreline at sunset looking out at an oil rig on the ocean.

items.synopsis: It could take hundreds of years — if not thousands — to reverse decline to ocean fish habitat if warming's not kept below climate targets, according to new research.

title.children: A 'double whammy' for fish — and humans — if climate targets are overshot

image.altText: Thunderbirds players stand on the podium as pink streamers fill the air

items.synopsis: As netballers approach a second week without pay, negotiations between Netball Australia and the Australian Netball Players' Association reach a stalemate. So, what are they arguing about?

title.children: Netball's pay dispute boils down to a lack of trust

image.altText: Chinese flags near the logo Evergrande Centre in Shanghai, China, on September 24, 2021.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest trading partner is facing its biggest economic slowdown in decades, and the Reserve Bank has warned that stress in China's economy will be felt across the world — including here in Australia.

title.children: How a 'sharp deterioration' in China's property market could affect housing affordability in Australia

image.altText: A man in a cap and glasses.

items.synopsis: Alan Leslie Graham was 79 at the time he was last seen in April 2016 at Angepena Station during a prospecting trip to SA's far north, and the state's coroner is now trying to piece together his final movements from witness testimonies.

title.children: Shoe sole and abandoned van among clues in outback disappearance of gold prospector

image.altText: A man looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Aboriginal people are considering what the Voice might mean for them, and if they want it at all. The ABC visited several regional communities in Queensland and listened. Here's what they had to say.

title.children: Fred has 'lost a lot of white friends' in the lead up to the referendum. He hopes they can reconcile their differences

image.altText: A woman sits on a park bench and looks at her phone.

items.synopsis: The telecommunications watchdog releases its annual report card on the country's telcos, and while complaints are down across the board, there’s one notable exception — Optus.

title.children: 'I don't have time to be fixing up big companies' errors': Industry report shows rise of complaints about Optus

image.altText: A close shot of Wong, wearing glasses and speaking, inside parliament house.

items.synopsis: Official advice to Australians looking to leave is to pursue commercial flights, however while flights out of Israel are available, there have been widespread cancellations.

title.children: 'All options' under consideration to get Australians out of Israel, amid calls for repatriation flights

image.altText: A young woman wearing sunglasses looks out a car window

items.synopsis: Tasmania's public housing overcrowding rates are higher than the national average and continue to grow, with one family in Hobart's northern suburbs given priority status still waiting after four years.

title.children: Katlyn's been told she can't get a bigger house for her growing family, so she drives around looking for one

image.altText: An Access Temporarily Damaged Sign next to the broken brick footpath from sand being eroded beside it.

items.synopsis: Approvals to fix a dangerously eroded Queensland beach drag out as residents fear their slice of paradise is slipping away into the ocean.

title.children: Coastal houses at risk of flooding as town's foreshore 'one big storm' away from collapsing

image.altText: A young woman with dark skin and black hair wearing yellow headphones looks at a yellow smartphone

items.synopsis: While some are optimistic about the streaming giant's move into audiobooks, others fear it will threaten authors' already precarious livelihoods.

title.children: Authors fear Spotify's move into audiobooks risks 'killing the golden goose'
